answers.author: Jesse Himes
answers.text:
Hi Melissa,
Finding the right insurance for employees is a tricky situation. I’ve found a few links from the Knowledge Network that may help you out!
The Center for State and Local Government Excellence has published a brief about how several city governments have addressed healthcare:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/303476/Health_Insurance_for_Active_and_Retired_City__Employees_Asheville_Denver_and_Oklahoma_City
One of our partners, Cigna, posted a blog about how to notify employees about changes in health insurance:
http://icma.org/en/BlogPost/1378/How_to_notify_your_employees_about_the_Health_Insurance_Exchange_Options_under_the_Affordable_Care_A
There’s also a ton of great articles and blogs under the Health topic area on the Knowledge Network:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/120/Health
I hope this is helpful and keep the great questions coming!
Jesse Himes, Knowledge Network Intern, jhimes@icma.org

author: Melissa Mundt
text:
The City of Ames has been asked to participate in an Accountable Care Organization with Wellmark Blue Cross and Blue Shield.  The first year we would be "testing" the program as a self-insured municipality as a demonstration.  
I am wondering if anyone out there has been participating this model of health insurance that is quality performance based?  If you have learned positives or negatives from participating??  We would like experiences for both for the municipal organization perspective and from an employee perspective.  We have five labor unions, so we approach changes with caution - even tests.  We have been told that employees should not notice much on their end, but we want to know that is the case from others that have participated this type of model.  
Thank you ICMA friends for any information you can share with me!
title: Accountable Care Community or Medical Home
